Back in 1928 the then great powers were manoeuvering for position in
the, Chinese aviation market - military and commercial.
The British
Through commercial Imperial Airwayd and military Far Bast Aviation.
The French were using their sphere of influence in Yunnan-fu later
called Kunming which they had joined to Hanoi in French Indo China
by a railroad
to promote French aviation.
flown a number of
French
planes
out to Indo China and
then on to Chungking where the
warlord of that province Liu Hsiang (sp?) was unable to
secure an im-
port permit to bring in airplanes, parts, gasoline or oil.
The
SO-
called
Central Government which controlled Shanghai would
not issue
its Huchow or import permit for any of the interior warlords but re-
served
The Germans had formed a company
called Eur-
asia which was owned
Government and
the German
Luft Hansa one third for the purpose of establishing air-
transport lines in China. C.M.Keyes, President of Curtiss Aeroplane
the Aviation Exploration Co. and organized
the Aviation Exploration do and organized an expedition to onit
under the leadership of our
old friend Wn. B. Robertson of St. Louis.
It was a bizarre collection of misfits.
A lawyer who knew nothing
whatever about Chinese Company law, while Shanghai had many able
American lawyers who did.
An
interpreter who spoke only Cantonese
to deal with officials who spoke only the northern dislect and
could
not understand a word he
said in Chinese but most of them spoke good
English so it didn't matter. A pilot with a Loening Amphibian.
They
negotiated an airmail contract with
Sun Fo the son of Sun Yat-sen the
George Washington of China but Sun Fo's reputation was sonething less
impressive than that of Caesar's wife.
Then too he was at
the time
Minister of Railways which Ministry had nothing whatever to do with
mail
as
that
was
the
business of
the Ministry of Communications.
contract was wonderful but it
just happened
The
fit.
mail
The Minister
to be with the wrong out-
or
make the
of Communications refused to give the company any
subsidy
he set up his
own
monoplanes to be
rival
payments
called for by the contract.
Instead
airline and bought five Stinson single motor
managed
and flown by Chinese pilots.
As
both companies
a result
lost money at
such an alarming rate that C. M.
Keyes
employed Max Polin, a Shanghai business man to work out a consolidation
of the two
companies.
to this proposal
The Minister of Communications readily agreed
under
because not only was his company losing money but
the Chinese management they were also losing airplanes and he
was quite prepared
to set up a new company under American
operating
managers.
The new
ed
company - China National Aviation Corp.
- was form-
with
the Ministry of Communications owning 51% and the
Curtiss int-
erests
owning
the other 49%.
The new company was to have
Shanghai to Peiping, Shanghai to Chungking
and
three routes
Chengtu,
Shanghai to
Canton.
There were
to be seven directors - four representing
the
Chinese interests
and three the American.
There were
to be
three
departments - the Business Dept. with a Chinese manager and an American
Assistant - the Finance Department with the
same arrangement and an
Operating Dept. with an American manager and a Chinese assistant. The
President was to be Chinese and
the Vice-President American. All
the
Chinese personnel wanted to get into the Operations Department because
employment
was secure there
ment usually
while in the Chinese run divisions employ-
ended with a change of political leadership - not infrege

ent because the Minister of
Communications seldom held office for more
than a
few years and each new appointee wanted to have his own team.
The company did not receive any
subsidy from the Chinese Government.
Its only revenue came from the
carriage of passengers and airmail
which was carried under a unique and most satisfactory arrangement.
If a letter was sent by ordinary mail the sender put on a five cent
stamp and from
that revenue the Post Office had to
pay for rail or
boat transportation.
If the letter was sent airmail the sender added
to the five cent
stamp whatever the airmail postage cost and
this entire
surcharge went to the airline. So that the premiun for airmail service
went to
the company which provided the expedited service while the
Post Office retained the five cents to cover local pickup and delivery.
Every six months the Post Office, with representatives of the airline
present, counted the number of units of mail
per kilo (2.2 lbs) and
that became the basis of payment by the Post Office to the airline for
the next
six months. The unit of mail was 20 grams and
the airmail
sur-
charge was 25 cents so that if each letter had
weighed
the limit or
20 grams there would have been 50 units of postage
per kilo but of
course many letters weighed much less than the limit and others which
carried two units of postage weighed less than 40
grams.
It happened
without exception that each semi-annual test showed
that the mail ran
84 letters or units to the kilo
SO
the airline got 21 dollars per kilo
or expressed in U.S. dollars at the average exchange rate about $3.20
per pound - a very good rate.
We had lots
of trouble in China with
"face" but we put that national
trait to
good
use
by advertising
that if your letter was important it
was sent by airmail.
The result was that many letters went by air
just because the
sender didn't want to lose face.
Pan American bought the American interest in C.N.A.C. in April 1953â€¢
The first meeting of the Board which I attended was
called to consider
whether or not the Directors would declare the company insolvent!
Under Chinese Company law if
the directors knew
or had reason to be-
lieve that
their company
was insolvent and failed to announce that
fact each of them was personally responsible for the debts of the
company. Actually the company had not been able to pay its bills for
oil
and
gasoline
and owed
quite a lot of money
to different suppliers
but it was pointed out to the
directors that with Pan American spon-
sorship things would get better - but we did not know just how.
any rate the directors agreed
to postpone the announcement and also
agreed
to eliminate a zone system which had been in effect for airmail
and follow Pan American's suggestion to have only one zone for all
China so
as to popularize and simplify the use of airmail. That was
the turning point and we soon started making modest earnings which
enabled us
pay off our creditors.
that time C.N.A.C. had
been so poor that no Chinese official had tried to get squeeze from
the company or put any of his poor
relatives on such an uncertain
payroll.
As we gradually got out of debt
and started to pile up
cash balances we
realized that a lot of cash would simply open the
doors to a flood
of demands from Chinese polititians for squeeze and
favors.
So realizing that polititians from F.D.R. down or up are
incapable of reading
or understanding a financial
statement we started
buying certificates of deposit from Chinese banks (at 8% interest)
and
carrying such in our financial statements as
"bills receivable"
SEPO-IST. PIOS

instead
of cash on deposit.
We showed a very small amount of cash on
deposit which was always smaller than our "accounts
payable"
and
the
Chinese politicoes still thought we were as poor picking as the mission-
aries and left us alone.
One one of my trips home the Comptroller of
Pan American asked why a company which sold its services only for cash
should have as by
then we did
three million dollars in "bills receivable".
When I told him the reason he hit the roof and we finally had to go to
President Trippe for a decision.
When the latter understood the situation
he had a good
laugh and
said "Bix - you win in a walk."
You will hear it
said that no company ever opperated in China without paying squeeze to
Chinese officials but we did.
The nearest we ever came to paying squeeze
was when I reluctantly agreed to the purchase of a white jade bowl which
was stolen from the Peiping treasures for presentation to an official
who was
retiring as President of the compant.
He had
purchased the bowl
and had
inscribed
on a little plate on the stand " to (his name) from
C.N.A.C. Your service to this company was like the quality of
this jade".
It was true that his
services were about as disreputable as the acquisi-
tion of that bowl.
He was the one who was describing a tiger hunt he had.
been on down in Indo China. It was at a dinner party given by the Minister
of Communications.
Our hero said that he was stationed in a small tree
with the bait - a lamb - tied to a stake below him.
The tiger walked all
around the tree before our Chinese friend
could get a bead on him.
I said
"K.C. if you had fallen out of that tree I'd bet
on you and
the first bite."
give
the tiger
The Minister nearly died laughing
particular Chinese was always called
"Tiger".
and
after
that this
Speaking of "squeeze" one of our pilots left the company and got a job
as
the representative of an aviation company intent
on selling aircraft
to the Chinese Government.
Not meeing with any success our ex-pilot
approached
the American Commercial Attache in Shanghai
and said
bluntly
"I want to know how you pay squeeze."
The Attache
rather
said
"that's
sort of asking how you make a girl - some you just say
"how's about it'
while with others you have to use a little more finesse."
